total.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: complete, or as great as is possible
total.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: a total ban on cigarette advertising
He looked at her with a total lack of comprehension.
a sport that demands total commitment
The sales campaign was a total disaster.
total.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: the final number or amount of things, people etc when everything has been counted
total.translation[1].definitions[0].note: the sum total (=the whole of an amount when everything is considered together)
total.translation[1].definitions[0].exam: That’s £7 and £3.50, so the total is £10.50.
A total of thirteen meetings were held to discuss the issue.
There were probably about 40 people there in total.
total.translation[1].note_box[0].section: The £1,750 raised by staff has been matched by the company, making a total of £3,500.
Police arrested more than 200 protesters yesterday, bringing the total detained to nearly 500.
He wants to add to his total of three Olympic gold medals.
Mrs Menzies said the final total could be as much as £750.
This was the sum total of her grandfather's possessions.
The Jones family has a combined total of 143 years' service with the company.
The Government plans to increase the annual total of 2,500 adoptions by up to 50%.
total.translation[2].definitions[0].exam: The group had losses totalling $3 million this year.
total.translation[2].definitions[0].note: Total is used especially in journalism. In everyday English, people usually say that something makes or adds up to a particular total:
total.translation[2].definitions[1].defi: to damage a car so badly that it cannot be repaired
total.translation[2].definitions[1].exam: Chuck totaled his dad’s new Toyota.
total.translation[3].definitions[0].defi: a chain of petrol stations in the UK, owned by the European company TotalFinaElf
total.translation[4].definitions[0].exam: The total cost of the project is put at £450 million.
a company with total sales of £12 billion last year
total.translation[5].definitions[0].defi: the final number or amount of things when everything has been counted or added together
total.translation[5].definitions[0].exam: What does the total come to?
We expect to raise a total of £3.6 million.
The jobless total is steadily increasing.
total.translation[6].definitions[0].defi: to add up to a particular total
total.translation[6].definitions[0].exam: Last year their sales totalled £364 million.

In order to receive benefits your savings must total less than £6,000.
